Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Regional Anesthesia in Kidney Transplant Recipients

Trial_Design.evidence: Patients were divided into two groups: Group A received ultrasound-guided TAP blocks, and Group B did not.

Participants.evidence: Conducted at Wellstar MCG, Augusta University, Georgia, USA, this retrospective study included 100 adult patients undergoing deceased donor kidney transplant, excluding those with opioid dependence.

Intervention.evidence: Group A received ultrasound-guided TAP blocks, and Group B did not.

Objective.evidence: This study assesses the impact of transversus abdominis plane (TAP) blocks on peri-operative analgesic use and side effects.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the use of intra-operative and post-operative analgesia up to 24 hours post-surgery.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Fifty patients were included in each group.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Fifty patients were included in each group.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Group A demonstrated a statistically significant reduction in intra-operative fentanyl use (p = 0.04).

Harms.evidence: No complications were recorded from TAP block use.
